nodes.bodyText:
I don't see the point of the two rules for "ya". The suggestion is the same in both rules. Is "ya" sometimes colloquial (as it is implied in the second rule) or is it always wrong?
And what about "y'a"? We need something similar to avoid this duplicate suggestion:
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -9007,6 +9005,31 @@ though, and has since been slightly modified)-->
         <example correction="trois fois par semaine">Je joue au Softball <marker>trois fois au semaine</marker>.</example>
       </rule>
       <!-- End of additions -->
+        <rulegroup id="YA" name="ya" default="temp_off">
+            <rule>
+                <pattern>
+                    <token>il</token>
+                        <marker>
+                            <token>ya</token>
+                        </marker>
+                </pattern>
+                <message>Ces deux mots doivent être séparés : <suggestion>y a</suggestion>.</message>
+                <example correction="y a">Il <marker>ya</marker> douze personnes.</example>
+            </rule>
+            <rule>
+                <antipattern>
+                    <token>il</token>
+                    <token>ya</token>
+                </antipattern>
+                <pattern>
+                        <marker>
+                            <token>ya</token>
+                        </marker>
+                </pattern>
+                <message>Cette formulation est considérée familière. Vouliez-vous dire <suggestion>y a</suggestion> ?</message>
+                <example correction="Y a"><marker>Ya</marker> douze personnes.</example>
+            </rule>
+        </rulegroup>
       <rule id="COMME_ME_LE_DIRE" name="comme me le dire accord">

commit.message: [fr] replaced replace.txt's ya with xml rule
[fr] added antipattern for false positives in our own rules

beforeCommit.message: [fr] replaced replace.txt's ya with xml rule

afterCommit.message: [fr] added antipattern for false positives in our own rules
